content: Chase Eck is a doctoral candidate in Economics at The University of Arizona. His research interests include the optimal design of transfer programs and the effects of occupational licensing in medicine on patients.
summary: Chase Eck is a doctoral candidate in Economics at The University of Arizona. His research interests include the optimal design of transfer programs and the effects of occupational licensing in medicine on patients.
title: Chase S. Eck

summary: We use regression and event study approaches to examine within-family changes in monetary transfers and informal care following wealth loss, involuntary job displacement, spousal death, and health shocks in retirement-aged households.
title: Adverse Life Events and Intergenerational Transfers

summary: We propose that multiparty negotiators respond to the complexities of their negotiation context by using strategy differently than dyadic negotiators and that one reason why is that they arrive at the negotiation table with weaker fixed pie perceptions than dyadic negotiators.
title: The “Fixed” Pie Perception and Strategy in Dyadic versus Multiparty Negotiations

content: Click the Cite button above to demo the feature to enable visitors to import publication metadata into their reference management software.Click the Slides button above to demo Academic’s Markdown slides feature.--
summary: Using plausibly exogenous variation over states and time I estimate that the introduction of EBT doubles the MPCf out of SNAP and accounts for 25 percent of its increase between 1990 and 2016.
title: The Effect of Electronic Benefit Transfer Cards on the Food Consumption of SNAP Recipient

content: Click the Cite button above to demo the feature to enable visitors to import publication metadata into their reference management software.Click the Slides button above to demo Academic’s Markdown slides feature.--
summary: I evaluate the degree of misclassification error when identifying job stayers in the Current Population Survey using the method proposed by Card and Hyslop (1997). I find that even though their method misclassifies approximately one-third of hourly workers, these errors do not substantially impact estimates of downward nominal wage rigidity, a common application.
title: Misclassification error when identifying job stayers in the Current Population Survey
